src/builtin/xor_codes/xor_hd_code.c.message: FWIW, this is where the bug is: when parity_index = -1, we underflow the array.

It's a little weird (especially given the comment) that this doesn't have a

 & ~((unsigned int)1 << data_index)

I have a couple of dumb questions (I classify them as dumb because I do not understand what this code does):

One. Why is the comment in singular? One element is masked off, but potentially you have more that you add.

Two. This masking by data_index appears to be redundant with what happens at the and of this function. Is it?

Reminder to myself (since I haven't looked at this in a while): this function is only used when we're facing three data failures, no parity failures.

On the first question, I may have extrapolated too quickly from the case that prompted the bug -- with a 6+6 4HD scheme, each parity is connected to exactly three data frags, so when we've found Q that hits all three failures and P that only hits two, we know that tmp_parity_bm will have exactly two bits set: one known and one unknown.

But there are other schemes that need to connect more than three data frags per parity -- for example, 12+6 4HD apparently needs six per parity. This probably should say something like "And any data elements they didn't have in common".

On the second, I was a little concerned about just doing

 *data_bm |= tmp_parity_bm;

then passing data_bm to fragments_needed_two_data. I hadn't dug into what the other fragments_needed_* functions might do with data_bm if it claimed to need something that we don't actually have. Tests pass when just using tmp_parity_bm but I don't know how good of a signal that is that it'd be safe.

If I keep this, it should probably have the

 (unsigned int)

cast that we've got below...

oslo_config/sources/_etcd3gw.py.message: So there's a problem here when using etcd3gw in that it uses requests. Since requests uses logging, when this attempt to output a log during the initial configuration, we attempt to read DEFAULT/logging_default_format_string. It ends up in a recursive failure because oslo_log wants this value but it needs to be read from a configuration file so we loop infinitely. The workaround I figured out was to raise the log level for requests/urllib3 but that's not ideal.

so the theory of why this should work is 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/migrate_data.py#L82-L109

this does 
  vif['delegate_create'] = self.supports_os_vif_delegation
where supports_os_vif_delegation is

    @property
    def supports_os_vif_delegation(self):
        return self.profile.get(OS_VIF_DELEGATION, False)

if the destination node is not patched and we are usign multiple port binidngs when it generates teh 
vif profiles the OS_VIF_DELEGATION flag should be omitted and as a result we will return false.

so get_dest_vif should have vif['delegate_create']==Flase for patched destination and true for patch destination which will set vif['delegate_create'] unconditionally.


for new spawns it does not go throught he migration_data code paths and on any host that has supprot for delegration it will just use it since we hardcode it and on host that dont have this patch applied it will use the old way.

so yes i think this will not break the migration code path for upgrade and will have the correct behaviour on both spawn and migration.

I don't have strong feelings about the emulation/client side of this, but it seems like this might be better off as two specs:
- expose an interface to get/set power state and get/set boot device
- develop a client for that interface inside sushy-tools

While I know sushy is an Ironic project, I suspect it could be more clear to talk about them separately.

Are we sure we want this integrated deeply into Ironic? I'd rather implement this as a separate server and client, and trust the client (in this case a redfish emulator) handle the credentials. I do not think it's a good idea to expose details/credentials about this emulation inside an Ironic node.

This is false. You're proposing adding 4 endpoints to the Ironic REST API. Details of those endpoints must be laid out here.

One thing I wonder about is
- Do the get calls return cached or real time data? Is it possible to specify cached or real time?

Again, this isn't true. You're proposing adding four endpoints which will have a direct change to the ManagementInterface. How will we handle situations where the underlying BMC doesn't allow "get" of power status or network devices? What about bmcs that don't have a concept of what disk to boot from?
sushy-tools was not designed to be used in production, it does not even have ANY authentication. If we think it's valuable, maybe we should add Redfish-compatible API to ironic proper?

I agree about the authentication; that's why the proposed solution does not involve storing credentials on the sushy-tools in any way, and uses keystone application credentials so that users have full control over whether access is even possible. That being said - if we can bring this functionality into Ironic proper, that would definitely be preferable! What would such a solution look like? Would we simply extend the Ironic API to mock a redfish interface?
Okay! I'll work on updating this spec then. Thanks for the feedback!

> Would we simply extend the Ironic API to mock a redfish interface?

Yes, why not?

Or we can provide another WSGI application that people can deploy if they want Redfish (can be a part of the Ironic repo, just not enabled by default).

is this order 6 just an example or is this a KVM requirement?

We have a case that a new instance cannot be brought up because of the order sixth requirement of KVM. However, I just want to give an example how that happen. And the big order pages shortage problem will happen in different call path.

qemu-system-x86: page allocation failure: order:6, mode:0x140c0c0(GFP_KERNEL|__GFP_COMP|__GFP_ZERO), nodemask=(null)

 alloc_pages_current+0x6a/0xe0

can you define what "strong enough" means here?

When the memory allocation speed is faster than the speed of asynchronous memory reclaim(kswapd), the number of free pages will continue to lower down to touch the min watermark. If kswapd is fast enough to reclaim the pages back, the number of free pages will climb up, and kswapd will stop until the high watermark hit.
You should also list the name of the new parameter added.
Thanks for the suggestion. I will review Brett's patch and see how the new parameter will be defined.

tune-watermark-scale-factor
This is implemented in the following charms' configs:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-nova-compute/+/792896
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-swift-storage/+/792899
this sentence could do with rewording, i'm not sure i understand what you mean.

The calculation of min watermark of each zone is by:

min(Zone X) = min_free_kbytes * percentage(Zone X)
percentage(Zone X) = managed_pages(Zone X)/sum(all zones' managed pages)

So, increasing the min_free_kbytes will increase the min watermark of each zone. Moreover, the gap is by default calculated by max(1/4* min watermark, 1/1000 * managed_pages)[1] with 4.15+(includes) Ubuntu kernel. Before v4.15, the only way to tune the gap is to increase the min_free_kbytes. If we want to increase to 1GB(4GB * 1/4) gap, there will be a 4G reservation with min watermark, and that implies the min_free_kbytes needs to increase 4x. The concern is that the memory reservation will be exaggerated if we want to fine-tune the watermark before v4.15. It is the trade-off.

[1]. __setup_per_zone_wmarks
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/mm/page_alloc.c#L8127
Suggestion: "to allow the configuration of the above values throught  charm parameters"

What do you mean by 'manual config'? To set it directly in sysctl? 
Also, I belive that this change could be more flexible if we had an additional parameter 'watermark-gap'. It would default to auto, and could be set to a value inside of a sane range, lets say, anything beteewn 256MB and 8GB. Auto would use your calculation as described.

The current implementation inside the charm-helper is using the 1GB as the default gap. The further fine-tuning needs to do the research in the labs in the future to see if the range tuning is benefit to the system. It's trade-off between the space v.s. performance.

The implementation:
Added watermark_scale_factor tuning #609
https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/609

Right, to set it directly through the sysctl as sysconfig charm did.

And your suggestion is good. However, tuning the memory fragmentation is not only the watermark. The /proc/sys/vm/extfrag_threshold is also one factor. And it could be brought into the charm in the future. I will try to figure out how to make this work together.

Can you envisage any potential regressions or notable changes in behaviour when going from a system that does not have this set to one that does? Would we want to allow this to be set without a reboot or only allow the change to take effect on boot?

Cons:
1). The kswapd will be awakened frequently than the one without increasing the gap. As the kswapd reclaims the pages more frequently, the swap will be filled up sooner, the page cache will be dropped more often, and the reclaimable slabs(for example, dentry caches.) will be dropped more frequently.
2). As the reclaim process getting more aggressive, the IO operation is increasing.

Pros:
1). Even the swap usage is increasing; the pages are reclaimed earlier to satisfy the real process requirement without resulting in i). memory allocation failure in big order allocation ii). synchronous reclaim hung(hit the min watermark). And the one *without* the mechanism will not reclaim the pages early. This will result in the process hit the min watermark repetitively and hang the userspace all the time. Also, when the min watermark is reached, the swap space is filled too. The swap space swapping ratio can be tuned by the /proc/sys/vm/swappiness. By decreasing the ratio to 0, the swap space will not be used until the (free pages + page cache) < high watermark[1]. It means the page cache will be flushed firstly to satisfy the reclaim. The persistent hugepages can be used to reserve the hugepages at boot time to satisfy the VM usage without allocating the 2MB THP(transparent hugepage) at run time.

[1]. get_scan_count
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/mm/vmscan.c#L2476
	if (sc->file_is_tiny) {
		scan_balance = SCAN_ANON;
		goto out;
	}
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/mm/vmscan.c#L2961
		sc->file_is_tiny =
			file + free <= total_high_wmark &&
			!(sc->may_deactivate & DEACTIVATE_ANON) &&
			anon >> sc->priority;

Finally, the config needs to be set to the sysctl config file and take effect in run time and also still take effect when the system is rebooted.
However, each system might have different memory capacities.

You're making a great point. We should just return a None value for the az attribute in the tuple then, hence letting the instance to be movable between AZs.
If operators wanna stick to a specific AZ *and* target a specific host, then they should use both --availability_zone (without the az hack) and --host then.
Agreed on the fact that old microversions would continue to have the AZ hack, but when saying "we already did that", where are we not calling this method if the user uses the 2.74 microversion ?

The logs are eventually there and the consensus is https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-06-28.log.html#t2021-06-28T13:25:49

1/ provide a new microversion for not calling the parse_az method
2/ modify the returned value of the az argument in the parse_az returned tuple, to be schedule_default_az option value.

We discussed this over IRC and the consensus seems to be two-case: 
* we propose a new microversion for stopping to support the AZ hack (ie. calling parse_az)
* we propose, instead of validating the input and breaking users, to modify the behaviour of parse_az which would return the value of the schedule_default_az config option for the returned availability_zone argument of the returned tuple (and log a warning besides)

This way, we would prevent a DB inconsistency by letting the instance to be movable (or stuck to a default AZ), and for operators who would both force a target and stick with another AZ, they could use --host and --availability_zone arguments (without the az hack syntax) post-2.74.

(fwiw, eavesdrop is lagging a bit so I can't provide the upstream resolution but you can see the conversation by https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-06-28.log.html once it's fully updated - for the moment, the HTML rendering bot is lagging but the raw logs are available on https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-06-28.log )

This is a dangerous behaviour. Operators who opt out from using the AZFilter would then see a huge upgrade impact as they would explicitely need to ask their end users to *not* use the availability_zone option when creating instances.

This code only triggers if you use the '--availability-zone az:host' option though (it's guarded by the 'if host or node' check), which means the 'AvailabilityZoneFilter' never had any part to play in this and never will. This code won't trigger for people using standard '--availability-zone az' (i.e. no host). Those will be handed by the AvailabilityZoneFilter as before, assuming it's enabled.
We would validate the requested availability zone against the host AZ even if the AZFilter isn't used, which would change the behaviour for operators not using it.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_collectd/t.message:
I believe that the change that introduced this issue [1] shouldn't have been merged. I think that it would have been better to add a new commone task in tripleo ansible and then call it in THT instead at [2] for example.

These tasks don't belong here in this create_persistent_directories task file. 
When I added this feature (collectd ansible) here and in THT, I was given feedback on the task naming, which I updated so debugging would be easier (i.e. when the all the tasks are combined for each stage that the debug messages wouldn't read "Error in collectd host_prep_tasks").
Since the same tasks were added to multiple roles, I'd suggest that DRY principles are observed and the tasks are put in their own role or a common library, so they can be called with relevant parameters in the THT files instead[2].
e.g. (in THT)

   - name: "Add fcontext entry for {{ service }} data"
     import_role:
        name: tripleo_common
        tasks_from: add_fcontext_entry
      vars:
        - target_dir: some/dir

Overall it'd would be easier to debug, and to grok what is going on at each stage.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/782393
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/metrics/collectd-container-ansible.yaml#L428

It would also be easier to maintain long term if this was some common task, so that if an issue comes up, it can be solved for all instances at once, instead of potentially seeing the same problem come up at different times.

glance_store/_drivers/cinder.py.message:
Am I to assume that we currently work against v2.0, or is 3.0 already the default, and we're just mirroring that here so it can be overridden by callers?

Also, is there any reason not to just set this to 3.54? That way we won't get halfway through some behavior, only to find out that the attachment part can't proceed if cinder is too old. If we have some minimum cinder version we require, we might as well require it everywhere to make it consistent and not have "everything is working fine until I go to attach..." behaviors.

We're currently working with v3 but there is no support to specify microversion, this parameter allows callers to specify the needed mv and the same cinderclient is provided. 3.0 is kept as it is the default used currently.

The reason I didn't set this to 3.54 as all the operations don't require that microversion.
The delete, get_size, configure_add and is_image_associated_with_store calls can work with 3.0 MV whereas the get and add (create) methods require 3.54.
Also it seemed confusing to me to set it to an arbitary 3.54, that's why I've set it to the lower 3.0 which currently cinderclient does if no MV is specified.

Yeah, I'm talking about a case where cinder and nova are not the same version. Not everyone upgrades all of their services every time, and not all at the same time. Some of the largest clouds leave some of their services on older versions because their API layers should still be compatible and there is no need to change them.

What you're introducing here is effectively a hard dependency on a new cinder (which is okay, not saying we shouldn't do that). All I'm saying is that it might make sense to bring all our calls up to 3.54 and not just the one we need. But, it's really not a big deal, just a "best practice" sort of thing.

well, the reason to pick the higher one is just because it may be confusing. Imagine an operator has a cloud running Wallaby, and they upgrade their glance and nova to Xena, but don't upgrade cinder because they don't think they need to. After glance comes up, they do a quick test to make sure that they can access the images stored in cinder, and they can. However, later the first user goes to upload an image and... they find out that we now require 3.54, and thus a new cinder. It's kinda their fault for not reading the release notes, but... they will won't be happy.

Anyway, if there are other changes we'd have to incorporate to bring the rest of the calls up to 3.54 then it might not be worth it, but, just something to think about.

Okay, I've been thinking about this a bit. The thing I'm focused on is making sure we log something useful to the operator and return something useful to the client. In retrospect, 500 is probably appropriate in terms of an error code, because it's indicating that there's something on the server side that needs to be fixed by the operator, and not something the user can do. It's unfortunate, because so many 500s *are* retry-able because they tend to be a catch all for "oops this failed now, but will work if you try again." In this case, it's an actual server error that won't work a second time, so even though most users probably will try, I guess it's the most appropriate thing.

So I think what's important is that we're logging something useful for the operator. Second most important is that we report something appropriate to the user.

Since I assume you've been testing this, can you show me what the log and 500 returned to the user look like? Maybe they're already suitable and sufficient. If so, I'll apologize for bringing it up :)

Okay, that's what I was asking originally: does it raise here or does it happen later?" If there's no exception here, then there's not much we can do other than probe to see if the version is supported.

It's entirely possible to have a very old cinder in a deployment. Many deployment tools (including Red Hat's) bring all the services forward together, but this is not always the case. Even though we're saying that we are requiring a new cinder at this point, I think we should make sure to handle the situation as robustly as possible, just so we can communicate what is going on instead of logging a stack trace or something else.

I'm guessing it will raise a ClientException when that happens, so the code in the next file will log it, but then re-raise that cinder exception up the stack. What happens in that case? As long as it's not a 500 or something to the user, I'm fine with it.

Okay, so that big stack trace is what I think would be nice to avoid. It makes it look like a bug, or something unexpected happened. IMHO we should only log a stack trace if something happens that we really don't anticipate, but this is something we know can happen.

Anyway, I won't hold this up further based on that, since the information about the microversions is in there on either side of it. Maybe we can follow up with a more concise log handler.

doc/source/admin/cpu-models.rst.message: operator right? Users can't request cpu models?
Ah yeah, I was using "user" in the generic sense here. Will correct

This is incorrect.

For AArch64 Nova sets ``max`` as the default CPU model.  It does the right thing in context of both QEMU TCG (plain emulation) and for KVM (hardware acceleration).

Also, AArch64 doesn't have a single default CPU model — the default varies depending on the machine type.  See more context here[2].  Hence we set "max" as the ideal model.

Please update the docs as per above.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/709494/21/releasenotes/notes/bug-1864588-737c29560effd16e.yaml

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/784066

specs/matrix.rst.message:
Monty just found that Linux Australia has started using spaces, so if you open up Element and enable the experimental spaces feature, you can see a public space here: https://matrix.to/#/#linux-australia:matrix.org

(You can also create private spaces, which is something I've been doing to organize the rooms I'm in.)
One additional benefit is the concept of "spaces" which allows for easier discovery of available channels for a given community (see https://element.io/blog/spaces-the-next-frontier/)
Element Matrix Services: https://element.io/matrix-services or ems for short.

Serveral folks trialling Matrix are doing so on federated homeservers.

The current OFTC portal room for #zuul has a canonical addres at :matrix.org (#_oftc_#zuul:matrix.org), and all of the IRC users are puppet users on that host, so they are effectively users of the matrix.org homeserver.  Several of us who are trialling Matrix have our own homeservers (myself, mordred, avass, SpamapS all have unique homeservers).  So whenever any of us talk with anyone in IRC (or a :matrix.org user such as TristanC), we're using federation to do it.  I haven't noticed any issues with latency, and no one has mentioned it, (though I haven't measured it).

While performance is quite good when users connect locally to the Zuul homeserver, did you recently test the performance of this scenario when users use matrix.org as their homeserver to access the rooms in a separate Zuul homeserver? Last I checked the performance was a bit hit or miss in that scenario.

From some of the other discussions, it sounds like we *definitely* want a mjolnir, which is like our current accessbot but also does federated access lists so we can collaborate with our other open source community friends on bans and whatnot. The nickel plan doesn't have it - so we'll likely want at least one level up. But - to the point in the doc, we should discuss this with Element Matrix Services.

If that's a long-term plan then the "self-hosted" option should probably be preferred, as the per-user cost can add up pretty quickly on an open EMS node... unless we get to some kind of arrangement with Element.io to limit spending.

Since I wrote this, I've been talking to folks who are either setting up or have set up Matrix for Fedora, Ansible, Gnome, and Mozilla.  The Fedora folks are planning an open-registration system, but with two homeservers:  fedoraproject.org to host rooms, and fedora.im to host users.  This is to address issues of project branding and sovreignty (do you want @bob:fedoraproject.org joining some random #room:matrix.org and everyone thinking he's acting on behalf of fedora?  What if he leaves the fedora project?  And what about creating ad-hoc rooms on the homeserver?  Suddenly #fuzzycats:fedoraproject.org is a real room).

This is good background: https://blog.ergaster.org/post/20210610-sovereignty-federated-system-gnome/

Here's my current thinking (influenced by Thib and mordred):

* Matrix user IDs are like email addresses.  :matrix.org is like @gmail.com.
* OpenStack doesn't issue email addresses to its contributors; maybe the policy should be the same for Matrix.
* If we ever did want to host users on a homeserver, we should follow Fedora's lead and have two homeservers for that purpose.

Small correction: apparently you can control who has permission to create room aliases on homeservers.  So my "fuzzycats" example isn't something to get too worried about.  The rest of the sovreignty concerns stand.

Yeah - what he said. As I've been talking more to Thib and reading his stuff - I believe we should stay out of the giving out homeserver accounts. The email analogy is the one that makes the most sense for this, especially where identity is implied at times by emails. The exception (like email) is when it's an open and generic service, like gmail or matrix.org.

We could decide (in the future - once OpenDev has an identity system) that OpenDev wants to be a general open system WRT identity so that an @opendev just means "I'm a user who uses OpenDev" - making OpenDev more like GitHub. I think an open registration homeserver *could* fit in to such a world - but I don't think we have the resources to tackle such a future vision.

Add:

Because Matrix can interoperate with other messaging systems, it would
also be possible for OpenDev to use its homeserver to host portal rooms
to other communities using other software (with their permission).
For example, OpenDev could host a bridge to k8s slack, making it simpler
for contributors to communicate with both projects.
This bullet looks incomplete. Maybe worth a follow-up to do: s/ (see/./
...or a failure of the OFTC bridge for Matrix, as we've observed multiple times since folks started leveraging this option.
This has probably already been covered, but is matrix.org reachable by users in mainland China without a VPN to obscure their connections? Anyone know?
I had been considering installing something like InspIRCd and Atheme services in a Zuul job to test our bots, which would in essence have been similar.

why do we need to call keys() at all?  Why can't we just do this?

for values in json_object.get('usage'):

I think most of the other py2 -> py3 conversion changes are following this pattern.  Anywhere that an iterator is being used, it is being explicitly converted to a list, even if its un-necessary.  The intention I believe to to make the new code act like the old code, even if the py3 version works without being converted.

For this particular usage, you can write it in many ways and achieve the same output, even without modifying it at all.
It is local so no need to make a copy.

There is just one usage of .keys in the whole repo, 8 .items(), 0 .values(). They can be grouped into a single review targeting .keys, .items, .values.

We don't need 2 reviews(.keys and .items) that can be easily reviewed as a group.
If we group the 3 of them(.keys, .items, .values) into a single commit, in the commit message we can specify that .values() didn't need conversion, that .keys() didn't need conversion(if we go that route).


Yes, there were reviews targeting only .keys, only .items, and only .values, but there were lots of instances across lots of files, to aid reviewing those were not grouped into a single review.

Yes, some unnecessary wrapping of iterators was used. There are reasons for following the list wrap pattern: 
1) In python2 the code was already creating lists, so the performance gain of using iterators wasn't present, so nothing was lost. 
2) Keeping the same object types in different places throughout the code makes sure the output is unchanged.
3) Not keeping the same object types requires more testing.
4) Seeing .keys, .items, .values, instead of direct iteration over the dict, is explicit, more readable and doesn't hide the fact that the object iterated over is a dict.

There is however a performance hit introduced during the conversion: I've seen throughout the repos that iterkeys, itervalues, iteritems were converted to non-iter variants. Will track this to be corrected.

ansible/roles/nova/tasks/remove_unused_s.message: If we have just performed an upgrade, can we guarantee that the old schedulers will be down, and that the new schedulers will have updated more recently than the old ones?
How do we know there has been sufficient time for the new service to register itself? Seems racy to me.

Yes, because during upgrade there is replacement of old containers by new containers. Then there is additional restart of container and some additional steps. And because old service was stored on different place in DB, so there is no chance to update that old entry. I think it is safe solution.

No, I don't think, because new service is started when old one is stopped and the code is done by that way that it will remove only service which has duplicate entry and only the older one. So it start to be duplicated only when new service (container) started and older is stopped.

Mark, I have to say that you were right. After few months of testing with this patch we hit this issue again. So we found different solution, where we are removing old schedulers from nova.services table, because between that releases there is difference that new schedulers are stored in nova_cell0.services table. So I think this solution can be proposed to specific version. But question is, if this shouldn't be solved during DB migration.

I would move this below the next list.
Also, why does not it happen by default with 'yes'?

1) The paragraph below is applicable to setting ``enable_ironic_ipxe: yes`` (and not overriding ``enabled_boot_interfaces``). Hence I suggested the move.

2) Hmm, but setting ``enable_ironic_ipxe: yes`` hijacks ``tftp_root`` so I assume pxe booting is b0rken.

I considered changing the order, but decided it made more sense to state that it is not enabled by default.

It doesn't happen by default because we don't try to manage all the lists of enabled and default drivers. We do it in kayobe and I wish we didn't. There is also some history, in that originally ipxe was enabled by setting ipxe_enabled = True in ironic.conf. Then it became a separate boot interface to allow mixing pxe and ipxe nodes in the same deployment.
